title: 114_s2280
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Pro bono Work to Empower and Represent Act of 2015" or "POWER Act". Congress acknowledges the high rates of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking, which harm vulnerable members of society. Efforts should be made to provide pro bono legal services and combat these forms of violence at all levels. Various factors contribute to such violence, requiring a range of solutions at local, State, and national levels. According to the National Network to End Domestic Violence, over 10,000 requests for services, including legal representation, were not met in a single day in September 2014. Pro bono assistance can provide legal representation, emergency shelter, transportation, and childcare. Research shows that legal assistance reduces the likelihood of future violence and helps survivors move forward by obtaining protective orders. Successfully obtaining a protective order against an attacker can prevent further harm to a victim and their family. A study showed that 83% of victims with an attorney obtained a protective order, compared to 32% without. The American Bar Association Model Rules emphasize the responsibility of lawyers to provide legal services to those in need. United States Attorneys have a duty to ensure equal justice. United States Attorneys have a duty to ensure equal and impartial justice for all citizens, including survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. They should encourage lawyers to provide pro bono resources to help victims escape the cycle of abuse and raise awareness of these issues nationwide. Communities can empower survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking by providing awareness of pro bono legal services and assistance. U.S. Attorneys to promote empowerment events for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Each United States Attorney must lead public events promoting pro bono legal services to empower survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Events should be held in partnership with domestic violence service providers, volunteer lawyer projects, and tribal organizations. Each United States Attorney is required to organize public events promoting pro bono legal services in collaboration with Indian tribes or tribal organizations to increase access to legal services for Native American victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The events should focus on maximizing local impact and providing high-quality pro bono legal services to survivors. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

Each United States Attorney must report to the Attorney General by October 30 each year on public events held under section 3 in the previous fiscal year. The Attorney General must then submit a compilation and analysis of these reports to Congress by January 1, including suggestions for improving future events.

SEC. 5. FUNDING.

The Department of Justice will use existing funds to implement this Act. Passed by the Senate on November 10, 2015, attested by Julie E. Adams, Secretary.
